Categorifying Hesselholt

Aug 17, 2020

In this post, I’d like to talk about some joint work with Ben Antieau, and, in particular, my understanding of how the story should go. This means in particular that all mistakes and misunderstandings are mine, and that some statements are just philosophical musings that are only mine. The ultimate goal is a categorification of Hesselholt’s -adic HKR theorem for a smooth algebra over a perfect field of characteristic . Before discussing this, it is a good idea to understand the situation for usual Hochschild homology and friends first, before proceeding to the topological version. As I’ve discussed previously, there is an equivalence (due to Preygel) between and for a field of characteristic zero and a smooth -scheme . This is not true in characteristic , and it would be good to give another argument for the characteristic zero which makes this failure in positive characteristic more explicit. More precisely, we would like to exploit the fact that the homotopy groups can be identified with a -periodic version of the de Rham complex . For the rest of this post, will be an arbitary ring (until we start to talk about the de Rham-Witt complex, at which point will be a perfect field of characteristic ), and will be a smooth affine -scheme. The affineness isn’t crucial.

In particular, it would be useful to give a construction of the category of D-modules directly from itself. There’s a way to do this with Koszul duality, etc., but we want a slightly different approach. Namely, we will describe a construction which assigns a(n -)category called to a complete filtered -ring, such that plugging in the Hodge-filtered de Rham complex produces the derived category of modules with a flat connection. The nice thing about this perspective is that we can see what fails in characteristic : it’s the fact that the HKR filtration on does not degenerate. In other words, you don’t get an equivalence of filtered -rings; rather, what happens is that itself admits a filtration (see here), denoted , such that the associated graded object is equivalent to (at least, after forgetting the grading on the ; I won’t care about the grading in this post).

We can now try to move on to the -adic context, and attempt to categorify Hesselholt’s equivalence . I’ll actually work with the equivalence from here stating for . What we would like, therefore, is some filtered category such that is equivalent to the -periodified category of crystals on . We first need to talk about a purely algebraic step, coming from this paper of Bloch’s. There, he shows that the category of locally crystals over is equivalent to the category of locally -modules with a flat de Rham-Witt connection whose -curvature is quasi-nilpotent. A de Rham-Witt connection on a -module is a map such that , where is the differential in the de Rham-Witt complex, and flatness just means that . A de Rham-Witt connection is said to have quasi-nilpotent -curvature if its mod reduction (which is a module over with flat connection) has quasi-nilpotent -curvature.

Before proceeding, let us observe that the local freeness assumption isn’t vital if we’re willing to work with derived categories. In that case, we get an equivalence between the ind-category of perfect complexes over (which are complexes of locally free finite type -modules) with flat de Rham-Witt connection and the derived category of crystals over . This is not essential, but to simplify some discussion, we will only work with the subcategory of (the derived category of) crystals whose associated module with de Rham-Witt connection has nilpotent (as opposed to quasi-nilpotent) -curvature. I’ll just call these “nilpotent crystals”.

One can show that the category of -modules (in the derived sense) with a flat de Rham-Witt connection is equivalent to , where just means the Hodge/stupid filtration on the de Rham-Witt complex. The derived category of crystals is a subcategory of , and it would be quite useful to describe this category without mention of “-curvature” (because it’s difficult to write down an analogue of this for ). Remember that the condition of having nilpotent -curvature was just a statement mod , so our task is to characterize modules over with flat connection with nilpotent -curvature. This can be done using the following theorem of Katz/Cartier: the subcategory of (i.e., modules with flat connection) spanned by those with zero -curvature is the essential image of the functor sending an -module to equipped with the canonical connection. Since the subcategory of spanned by those with nilpotent -curvature is the thick subcategory generated by those with zero -curvature, we conclude that the subcategory of spanned by those with nilpotent -curvature is the thick subcategory generated by the image of the functor .

In conclusion, the derived category of nilpotent crystals is the thick subcategory of generated by the image of the functor
